comments.text:
+SideWays8Productions I guess that settles eu vs us cars, they just have

comments.author: Reinis Aizsilnieks

comments.text:
+Reinis Aizsilnieks Sorry I had missed your comment back in December. Where 
I'm at the most inexpensive vehicles are full size pickup trucks or beat 
down Chevrolet S-10's. Which can be picked up for $500-$1000 US... ANYTHING 
that I would prefer for rally (Old Subaru Impreza or Legacy for example) IF 
I can find one is always an automatic transmission. Next in line would 
probably be Honda Civic's but I just recently took my 95 civic out in the 
mountains and I really don't like the feel of the way FWD slides around 
corners in gravel. Granted, it's my only vehicle right now and has 
performance road tires so I didn't want to tear them up and beat up my car 
too much - that and with 205/45/17 tires anytime I hit ice I simply slid. 
But it didn't do to bad, so I guess it'd be somewhat different if I had 
narrower tires that were good on gravel and it wasn't my only vehicle so I 
could throw it around more. But I also live in a rather small town setting 
that would be classified as "redneck" so most everything is pickup trucks 
and/or automatic... neither of which I like for rally... and I kind of 
doubt automatics are allowed in events.
comments.author: Ace Night

comments.text:
+Reinis Aizsilnieks In the states we call them "indicators" or "turn 
signals." A few years ago, the color of the lens itself used to be an ugly 
yellow, but now most cars just use a brake light for a turning signal 
(which is very hard to tell in heavy traffic, since you don't know if 
they're braking or merging). I know most Japanese and European market have 
clear lenses with yellow bulbs, making for a much cleaner and nicer 
aesthetic look, which is why they're so sought after in the states.

The JDM version of one of my car's tail lights are so expensive for the 
sheer fact the turning signal lamps are clear and not yellow lol
comments.author: SideWays8Productions

comments.text:
+SideWays8Productions Most young adults here own 80s 90s audis, or e36 e30 
e29 bmws. And the feuds are same like american cars vs japcars. None costs 
more than 2k eur. A lot of those cars you can get for less than 1k eur. 
Have friends who have bought cars from usa, and its not that expensive, 
except the problem is with car standarts, like i dont know the english term 
but the flashing lights before turns for example are in different colors. I 
guess thats why those cars are expensive there, they are made for european 
standarts, and changing them to usa standarts is expensive, same with us 
cars in europe, thats why theyre expensive here. After all these comment 
feuds, this is first time when i thought of this.
comments.author: Reinis Aizsilnieks

comments.text: He says European Rallycross
comments.author: Bogs Binny

comments.text:
+Reinis Aizsilnieks Here in the states we really only go by vehicle class. 
It's either categorized into 2 wheel or 4 wheel drive cars, modified or 
unmodified cars, or engine size/power levels, or any combination of those. 
Beginners and pros alike use anything from old BMWs and Toyota Celicas, to 
Ford Focuses and Subarus, whatever they can get their hands on. A rally 
team I met last year is even building a Lamborghini Gallardo rally car to 
compete in open unrestricted classes. Although most vehicle classes require 
certain safety standards be met in order to race. For the class I enter in 
NASA rallies, I need at least a 6 point welded roll cage, 1 piece racing 
seats (non reclinable), racing harnesses, a fire extinguisher, an 
electrical circuit killswitch, and a helmet. I know in Europe some racing 
series are a lot more lenient with car safety and probably don't require 
that many things, which makes for much cheaper rally cars lol

Oh, and Audi 80's are very expensive and rare here :(
comments.author: SideWays8Productions

comments.text:
+Ace Night I dont know hows its in usa, but in eastern europe, get audi 80 
quattro 2.3, which costs abot 1.5k eur, and its enough to start in 
different race types, or some golf2 / golf 3, and its fine for local 
offroads
comments.author: Reinis Aizsilnieks

comments.text:
+Ace Night Best advice I can give is get your name in as many different 
things as possible. If you have a versatile enough car, get into autocross, 
local rally events, drag strip events, travel to a decent track for an open 
track day, etc. Look into racing schools or seminars, regardless of type. 
If your local oval track has sort of an entry level nascar class and it 
fits your budget, take it. Why not? I'm only 20 but the past 3 years I've 
taken my STi in autocross at Giants Stadium, NASA rally events in upstate 
NY and PA, "Evo vs STi" days at Englishtown drag strip, a few SCCA open 
track days at NJMP, etc. Also, look into some sort of journalism for local 
events. Not a lot of people cover the local rally events here so I meet a 
lot of connected people simply because I'm there taking pictures and 
broadcasting the standings on my twitter, instagram, etc. The more people 
you meet and the more involved you get, the further you'll get. It'll also 
help to look into an SCCA license and other racing licenses. Some events 
require it, so if you have it you can compete in bigger events.

+Reinis Aizsilnieks in most parts of the US, race tracks are scarce. In the 
northeast where I'm from and the northwest where he's from, either not a 
lot of people are into racing, the surrounding land isn't suitable to build 
one, or the local economy can't support one. In the southern US where the 
land is flat and open and a lot of big local economies are, race tracks are 
everywhere. Florida, Texas and southern California have many race tracks. 
And most of the professional racing in America is done through connections. 
Travis Pastrana, Bucky Lasek and Ken Block all have big connections to Red 
Bull and other sports organizations, so it was easy for them. I know for 
sure Mitchell Dejong got into the GRC Lites division because his father is 
a mechanic for the Red Bull team. Tanner Faust is a host of Top Gear US, 
Nelson Piquet Jr is the son of the F1 driver Nelson Piquet, the list goes 
on. Which further emphasizes my point, you're gunna need a lot of 
connections to get places in American racing lol
comments.author: SideWays8Productions

comments.text:
+SideWays8Productions By the way, got any suggestions for someone trying to 
get their foot in the door with racing in the states? About as far as I've 
gotten is get $5,000 together and go to the Racing School at Portland 
International Speedway and get my racing license.
comments.author: Ace Night

comments.text:
+Reinis Aizsilnieks I live down by Roseburg, Oregon and we have 1 track, 
which is an oval track. DC Speedway, it was a 1/8 of a mile oval or 
something like that, and got upgraded to a 4/10 of a mile oval a few years 
back. The only other one I know of in Oregon is the Portland International 
Speedway. Washington (where I used to live) has 21 race tracks according to 
http://racingin.com/track/washington.aspx most of which are about 1/4 mile 
and I saw one 1/2 mile and one at 2.3 miles.
Oregon has 19 according to the same website, though I didn't see any indoor 
cart places and I saw one down in Medford the other day. But I saw at least 
4 drag strips. 

So I would venture other states have at least that, but really there isn't 
a lot of promotion to professional racing... except toward Nascar. Over on 
the west coast all I hear about is local kart, hornet, and street stock 
racing. Otherwise it's Nascar. The only reason I know what Le Mans is is 
because I ran across it on the Speed Channel when I was 15 or so (2006). I 
know there's an offroad series also which is pretty cool. There is 
literally no promoting of anything (that I'm aware of) in the states for 
anything but local 1/4 mile oval races, drag races, or Nascar.

The only reason I ran across WRC and McRae and Loeb is youtube. I had ear 
surgery a month ago yesterday and ran across rally videos at random and 
have fallen asleep to the sound of Loeb tearing up the stage literally 
every night.

But, in reality, as a 23 year old American who loves to drive fast 
everywhere possible, and having been belittled by the "American Muscle" 
types because I want to drive fast in more than a straight line, and 
mothers because I have a 4 year old son, it is hard to achieve anything but 
a local track career. The most majority of Americans aspire to is Nascar... 
very few people I've met look overseas for anything but a vacation 
destination. Americans like SideWays8Productions and myself that aspire to 
reach competition in a foreign country are a rarity (other than maybe 
soccer/football). I look at the drivers in WRC, especially Loeb seeing as 
he dominates WRC, and I admire their abilities and it brings out the 
competitive nature I have, and I want to reach them and when I do, I want 
to pit my skills against there's. This is a mentality that seems to have 
died off in American culture.
comments.author: Ace Night

comments.text:
+SideWays8Productions Well, arent there red bull free competitions, for 
kart racing, etc, a lot of wrc, f1 and LeMans drivers are champions of 
amateur kart races, where there is no entry fee. And a lot of those racers 
come from poorer countries, and poorer families. And really, are there 
really race tracks so spread out? I live in 1 of poorest countries in EU, 
and small one too, Latvia, near each city we have 3-5 race tracks for 
different types of racing, street, dirt, auto-cross, mx,, drift, karts, 
drags, supermoto
comments.author: Reinis Aizsilnieks

comments.text:
+Ace Night That's exactly my point to the T. American "racing" is so 
sheltered and close knitted, it takes decades to expand. People get 
immersed in one form of it and settle for the rest of their lives. Drag 
racers build these awesome 6 second cars (I respect a well built machine, 
regardless of sport lol) but that's it. They get their strip times every 
weekend and they're happy. The JDM time attack kids with their whacky aero 
kits and rivets get so immersed in lap times, and that's it. Americans 
rarely expand to other forms of racing and that's why you rarely see 
Americans in international racing series. My aspirations are to be a WRC 
driver or a World Endurance driver in Le Mans, specifically for Aston 
Martin. I'd also love to be an F1 driver if ever faced with that 
opportunity, I'll even be a World Touring Car driver if I had that 
opportunity as well. Because the way I see it, the more experience you have 
under your belt, the further you can go. F1 is gunna take a world champion 
rally, Le Mans and WTCC driver over a 16 year old kid who's father won a 
few podiums back in the 80s (coughRosbergcough). And you rarely see that in 
America because no one has that mentality. Everyone settles with one type 
of car or one type of racing and they get no where. They can be the best 
time attack driver in Leguna Seca, but they'll ONLY be that. OP said 
Americans aren't skilled enough to be in the WRC, and I tried to tell him 
it has more to do with opportunity than it does skill.

And my comparison between America and Europe was in a demographic sense. 
Europe has twice our population, but only half of the countries have 
developed infrastructure and government to compare to America (i.e., 
excluding south/south-eastern Europe, etc). And among that population, a 
lot more people are associated with motorsports. Whether it be actively 
competing in a series, or just a car enthusiast in general. Not to mention 
the driving skill of Europe in general is a lot better than Americas lol I 
can't begin to count how many times a dumb broad in a Range Rover almost 
rammed me off the road when approaching a slight bend lol
comments.author: SideWays8Productions

top_comment.text:
I am surprised that many people, mostly Americans I believe, haven't heard 
of Sebastian Loeb. How can you be a racing/rally enthusiast and not heard 
of him? A 9 time World Rally champion, who has won rallies on every surface 
- tarmac, gravel, snow, mountain roads - you name it. He will easily adjust 
to any surface or race structure Ken Block is an expert in, and will 
comfortably beat him there. For a comparison, Ken Block has entered the 
World Rally Championships, and finished 7th in the Mexico Rally, his best 
result to date.﻿

top_comment.text:
voice of reason for a minute, everyone disses Ken Block hard all the time, 
in fact it seems to be a global sport of sorts, but the thing is, he held 
second against the majestically talented Sebastian Loeb. A no hoper with 
zero talent could not do that in truth. Dont get me wrong, I am New 
Zealander that admires Ari Vatanen more, but to claim he is a no talent is 
just inaccurate. He certainly is better at hyping himself than letting his 
actual skills do the talking Ill grant you that, but the guy isnt a zero 
talent. ﻿

all drivers make mistakes. But man he is no joke bro.
